contentrichtext.text: ''Not to be confused with [[Ponginae]]'' {{Taxobox | name = '''Pongids''' | fossil_range = Late [[Miocene]] to Recent | regnum = [[Animalia]] | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Mammalia]] | ordo = [[Primates]] | subordo = [[Haplorrhini]] | infraordo = [[Simiiformes]] | parvordo = [[Catarrhini]] | superfamilia = [[Hominoidea]] | familia = '''Pongidae''' | subdivision_ranks = Genera | subdivision = *''[[Gorilla]]'' *''[[Orangutan|Pongo]]'' *''[[Pan (genus)|Pan]]'' }} '''Pongid''' refers to members of the [[taxon]] '''Pongidae'''. They are sometimes called '''great apes'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pongid definition|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/pongid}}</ref> Pongidae is now known to be [[paraphyletic]]. Pongids gave rise to [[hominins]] around seven [[mya (unit)|mya]].<ref>{{cite book|editor=Peter S. Ungar|year=2007|author=Cordain, Loren|title=Evolution of the human diet: the known, the unknown and the unknowable|chapter=Implications of Plio-pleistocene diets for modern humans|quote="Since the evolutionary split between hominins and [[pongids]] approximately 7 million years ago, the available evidence shows that all species of hominins ate an omnivorous diet composed of minimally processed, wild-plant, and animal foods.|pages=264â€“5}}</ref> The corresponding [[crown group]] for this taxon is [[Hominidae]]. Pongidae has 6 extant member [[species]]. This taxon is rarely used today but is of historical significance. ==Distinction to hominins== {| class="wikitable" |- ! !! Pongids !! Humans<ref group="notes">[[Humans]] are the only extant [[hominins]].</ref> |- | Mode of locomotion || [[Knuckle walking]], [[arboreality|arboreal]] || [[Bipedalism]] |- | Location of [[foramen magnum]] || Back of the skull || Under the skull |- | Average brain capacity || 400 [[Cubic centimetre|cc]] || 1700 cc |- | Skull (viewed from top) || pear-shaped || ovoid |- | Widest part of skull viewed from behind || Parietal region || Base of the skull(near the auditory region) |- | Palate || Rectangular || Parabolic |- | Body Growth || Fast || Slow |- | [[Phalanges]] || Curved || Straight |} ===Skull=== The pongid skull contains the following [[symplesiomorphy|features]] that are absent or less pronounced in humans: *a [[sulcus (morphology)|sulcus]] behind the brow ridges *[[prognathism]] *a protruding [[occiput|occipital]] region *large, bony eye sockets *a large nasal opening *constriction just behind the orbital region *stout facial bones *a [[diastema (dentistry)|diastema]] *a [[simian shelf]] ===Adaptations for locomotion=== The following adapatations are for arboreal and knuckle walking locomotion and are not found in humans: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Pongid !! Human |- | Arms are as long as or longer than the legs || Arms are shorter than the legs |- | [[Scapula]] has an orientation for supporting the body weight beneath the arms || Scapula is oriented for holding the arms by the side |- | [[Digit (anatomy)|Digits]] are long and curved for grasping branches || Digits are shorter and straight |- | [[Pelvis]] is shaped to support the legs and trunk in the bent-over posture || Pelvis is shaped to support the legs and trunk in a vertical position |- | Knees do not lock the legs || Knees lock the legs straight to minimize the expenditure of energy when standing |- | Pelvis is relatively large || Pelvis is much shorter and bowl-shaped |- | [[Ilium (bone)|Iliac]] pillar is elongated || The iliac crest is oriented more to the side and slanted |} ==Similarity to hominins== The [[australopithecines]] show intermediate character states between pongids and humans, with ''[[Pithecanthropus]]'' intermediate between australopithecines and humans. Members of the genus ''[[Homo (genus)|Homo]]'' share many key features with anatomically modern man. ==See also== [[History of hominoid taxonomy]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Reflist|group=notes}} *[http://origins.swau.edu/papers/man/hominid/ Science and faith: The hominid fossil record] ==External links== *[http://h2g2.com/dna/h2g2/alabaster/A918399 Pongidae - the Great Apes Family] *[http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/6812430 Brain endocast asymmetry in pongids] [[Category:Obsolete taxonomic groups]] [[Category:Apes]]
